justification: The review notes that "Common subconstructs include kinesiophobia… fear of movement…" and states that "the most commonly used questionnaires (TSK, FABQ) were criticised," indicating TSK is the typical instrument for kinesiophobia / fear of movement-related pain.

The paper reports that "activation of certain fear-related areas correlates with high TSK and FABQ scores, indicating that the different constructs 'fear of (re)injury' and 'fear-avoidance beliefs'."  Here FABQ scores index the fear-avoidance beliefs construct.
Within the study descriptions, several trials list "Pain catastrophizing: PCS" as a self-reported variable, showing PCS is the scale used to quantify the pain-catastrophizing construct.
Study tables included in the review specify "Fear of pain: FOPQ" among the self-reported measures, demonstrating that the FOPQ operationalises the pain-related fear construct.

measured_by: Positive Affectivity and Negative Affectivity Scale (PANAS)
justification: Several experimental studies are described as collecting "Positive and negative affect: trait version of the PANAS," indicating PANAS is the instrument used to measure the affective construct of positive/negative affect.
